intro: Chloropyron parryi, commonly known as Parry's chloropyron, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
